This might be better than "No Way Home" and definitely served as a prototype for that live action movie.  Who knew an action sci-fi cartoon could be better than it's live action counter-part?!  But the script here is so strong.  It takes you by surprise with it's inventiveness.  Plot wise this mixes together as aspects of the standard Superhero origin story; which is expected.  But then it brings in It's a Wonderful Life and Christmas Carol; where the ghosts of Christmas past so to speak; (in this case other versions of the hero himself; from different dimensions) coach the hero and train him, a la Obi Wan Kenobi, to rise to the occasion of his super hero calling.  It's a wonderful plot; building on the whole idea of past franchise cast members joining the movie as characters from a different universe; or dimension; a conceit cleverly started by Jeremy Abrahams' Star Trek years ago.  A wonderful story and a wonderful cast; wonderfully inventive; great chemistry between the actors; the story consistently surprises you; and you leave the theater definitely hungry for a second course!  I can't wait to see the next installment in June!  Highly recommend!

What a way to end 2022! I watched this film when it came out in 2018 and hadn't revisited it. Let me tell you that my opinion has changed a lot since then. I truly believe that "Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse" is the best Spider-Man movie ever released. 

I love everything about this movie. The animation (though it took a minute to adjust to) is gorgeous and unique. The cinematography is breathtaking. There is emotional complexity to this movie and an incredible depth to each character (especially Miles). The "all is lost" moment is masterclass storytelling and creates a near-perfect finale.

"Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse" showcases why film is my favorite medium for storytelling. 

Best Character: Miles (honorable mention to Peter B. Parker)
Best Scene: Leap of Faith (Top 10 all time)
Best Quote: "Anyone can wear the mask. You could wear the mask."
Best Song: "What's up Danger"

Note: Stan Lee's cameo is this movie is an all-timer.

Spiderverse is a triumph in animation. It manages to be an un-selfserious adventure romp with smirky dialogue and absurdist silliness, while deploying some of the most creative cinematography I've seen in any film - superhero or no. It seemlessly blends trendy modern styles and music with a vividly 'on the page' comic-book aesthetic. It is just as contrived as the next comic book movie, and even more lighthearted. Yet somehow it feels so much more grounded in the lives and emotions of actual people. The now souless and repetitive comic book movie landscape is here completely disrupted with something altogether more ambitious, artistic and - genuinely - funny.

All in all, this film does everything that animation should give you the freedom to do. Go big, go crazy,  go creative.

This is a fast paced, high action CGI superhero universe film that I very much enjoyed. I loved that there was an anime character and other decent female characters and the CGI was pretty impressive. I particularly liked the times when speech from the comic book that the film seems to be set in, appears on screen - this doesn't happen all the time but from time to time and its quite amusing and visually appealing. I suppose its a little bit like the old Batman live action show, with one or two times where noises made appear on screen, like 'bonk' etc.

This film should appeal to action film fans - although it is CGI, its very fast paced and engrossing and I wouldn't say its entirely meant for young children - it can be enjoyed by an older audience too but would certainly entertain youngish people as well, so its a bit of an all rounder.I very much enjoyed this - I think it's a film that's probably worth a re-watch or two because there's so much going on that it'd be easy to miss little clues and details while watching the main action on your first view. I'll watch it again at some point and see if I'm right about that or not but otherwise, yes, I'd certainly recommend this film as a decent, solid bit of action packed entertainment. I wouldn't necessarily say it's a film with a lot of thought provoking aspects as such but for what it is, it's a very good film regardless.

But the charm and memorable design make this a mute point overall. Easily not just a classic super hero or animated movie but this is A All Time Classic in General.

"Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse" is a fantastic film but might be a bit overwhelming for some viewers. It's filled with blaring hip-hop music and the animation is beyond splashy...it's competely intense! Now these are NOT criticisms...more a warning if you hate these sorts of things or if you or someone you loves has challenges, such as Autism....as the film might really be overwhelming. Still, I'm nearly 55 and loved the picture...and I think most will if they have an open mind and want something different. That DOES strongly apply to me, as I've gotten sick of superhero movies because there have been so many recently and there's a certain sameness about them...but not this Spider-Man film!

The story is told with breathtaking CGI--with a look that is nothing like any other film I've ever seen. In this world is a young man who sees Spider-Man killed and is also bitten by a spider and becomes the next incarnation of Spider-Man. But instead of taking the time to enjoy and learn about his new powers, this young man finds himself in the middle of a weird apocalyptic occurance---and all the various incarnations from the various universes come together to save the day.

Overall, amazingly creative...there's nothing else like it. This is more than reason enough to see it. Sadly, however, the film loses a bit on home TVs...even big ones as the scale and size of the film needs the big screen.

The best Spider-Man movie ever after the first two Sam Raimi movies and No Way Home and the best animated movie after WALL-E and Batman: Mask of the Phantasm. The ground-breaking 3D-2D comic book CGI animation is so unique it looks like the evolution of visual art and it reminds me of the art style from the Ultimate Spider-Man and Spider-Man Shattered Dimensions game. This movie is about representation, inspiration, interacting in your revolutionary-looking world, and becoming your own icon. Miles Morales is the second best coming-of-age character to be Spider-Man.

Being Spiderman in movies isn't easy. We always have high expectations for this iconic hero. And you know what? This movie reaches and passes them easily. Everything here is perfect. You can just be watching a well-done action scene, enjoying a beautiful and accurate soundtrack, having fun with perfectly timed jokes (it's serious or fun when it has to be) or maybe crying because something heartbreaking happened. Also, there are spidermen for everyone. Are you a young teenager? No problem, you will identify with Miles leading with all the changes he's going through. If you are a late teenager, you will understand the reason for all Spidergwen's actions. Besides, for old people, there will be Peter B. Parker being everything you expected from someone who's in his 30's or 40's and has to face the world.

This movie has no flaws. It gets everything right and has an evident care for our beloved web head. This movie is a testament to Spiderman and all the fans who have stuck with him for the past sixty years, young and old. The animation is beyond perfect and the tiny details, the creativity, and the genius of this movie never fail to amaze me. The voice actors are perfect for their respected roles and every line is delivered with such wit. The story is flawless and neatly paced with witty humor, drama, and creative action scenes all in one. But what I love most about this movie is it's unique understanding of our friendly neighborhood Spiderman. It understands what it's like to be the underdog, fighting a battle when you don't know how to fight, constantly failing yet refusing to fall. Into the Spider-verse has such a clear comprehension on what it means to be Spiderman. Anyone can wear the mask because all it takes is the courage to get back up after getting beat down, which I find is Spider-man's most important trait. Spider-man always gets the worst luck and yet continues to fight on because it's his responsibility. No matter what happens, he finds a way to perservere because it's the right thing to do. It was an interesting choice using Miles Morales as the protagonist and I think it made the movie all the more special, telling the story of Spiderman from a different, refreshing perspective while maintaining the heart of its origins with Peter Parker. There is so much right with this movie.

Why did it take me so long to see this? A wonderfully imaginative and creative blast that harnasses the unique possibilities of animation and the best of the superhero genre with wit and intelligence to produce something new and different. Unlike many new and different pieces of art, however, it's also warm and inviting. Brilliantly animated, acted, and directed, it has uplifting ideas about diversity and inspiration without being too sentimental or 'life lesson' of the worse type. Possibly a shade too long - or that may be a tired, Covid recovering viewer speaking - but all in all it's a brilliant acheivement.

It's refreshing to see an animated Spider-Man sequel for  a change. Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse is groundbreaking in many ways. Its unique style of animation would make you feel like you're watching a comic book come to life. It's almost like a full-length motion comic movie. The sound editing and musical score also helped create the different moods. Although there were times when it was too loud and a bit overdone. The addition of comics-style narration and comic book sound effects was a great idea. The story itself was alright. The movie is full of action, chases, twist & turns and character interaction. A little bit fast-paced, but it's a very entertaining audio-visual treat!

Aside from that, everything was fantastic.

Visually this movie looks great, especially with its creative use of camera angles. The action was great to look at, a lot of the comedy landed perfectly, and when it got serious it did that very well. This was the first time I had ever seen Miles Morales and he was a joy to watch, he's written excellently. I had previously seen Gwen and of course Peter, and they were great in this movie as secondary main characters. The other three members of the team didn't get much time to shine, but I think it was better to focus on the main three rather than sacrifice some of the time they got or make the movie much longer to flesh out six different protagonists.

(No Spoiler Review!)

This is, in my opinion, the best movie adaptation of a superhero comic that has ever been produced. All the characters are interesting and memorable, and, while there are many characters in the film, it doesn't lose sight of the fact that it is a Miles Morales origin story. The animation is outstanding, and mixed with the superb voice talents, great soundtrack, and interesting story, it makes for a great time! On a side note that is more opinion than fact, if you have never read a Miles Morales or Spiderverse comic, I recommend NOT reading any before watching this film, to prevent any surprises from being ruined! Incredible movie. A bit late for this review, as the movie came out 3 years ago, but to this day it remains my favourite movie. The animation is so smooth, and there are so many details going on. The rewatchability of this movie is incredible. The soundtracks really compliment to the mood, and are incredible on their own. The messages and ending keeps you on the edge of your seat, with the gripping last fight scene keeping you extremely invested in the movie. You can feel yourself relate and root for Miles, and you can really see his emotions alongside him. Absolute hands down an incredible movie, and my favourite ever. It doesn't delve into the typical gore genre of superhero movies to keep the viewers invested, and can be watched by all ages. Best to watch at home though for a few people, as the effects in the theaters may be a bit too much (especially older citizens). The movie also has some very funny moments that are perfect for each situation, unlike other movies that use jokes halfway through the climax. Would definitely recommend to anyone who enjoys films in general. 10/10. The animation is smoother than water, the acting is just perfect, the jokes land right on target, and the movie in general keeps you glued to the story. Hyped up for the sequel coming out next year. Definitely recommend, 10/10.

The perfect Spiderman movie and one of the most perfect animated movies to debut. "Spiderman: Into the Spider-Verse" tells an incredibly moving story that has powerful messages throughout. The animation is phenomenal, and is done in a way to make it seem like an actual comic book is coming to life in front of your eyes. This is easily the most comical of the Spiderman films, even bringing in several references to the comic books themselves. The humor is handled very well, and the banter between Miles and Peter, Miles and Gwen, and Miles and his dad, Jefferson, is extremely entertaining to watch. The villain is also one of the best to ever hit the screen, being a villain that you feel sorry for and even begin understanding his motivations for what he does and why he does it. However, I think where this film really shines is in its action, which is done so well and is so fun to watch. The cast is absolutely perfect, and the ending will leave fans dying to see the sequel.

This movie is just amazing: 
1. The animation is insanely unique and the perfect style for this world: so vibrant and colorful with striking and memorable imagery in almost any scene.
2. The story balances multiple characters but gives each of them great moments and development. Miles is a perfect protagonist for this story, the slight subversion on the older Spider-Man fits, Kingpin is given enough backstory to understand, and the Prowler twist is handled so well. Amazing voice acting for each of these characters as well.
3. The plot should be all over the place, but the writing and directing smoothly moves you through this movie like you're turning the pages of a comic book.
4. I really felt the weight of this world and the characters: when Spider-Man is killed, I am reacting in the same way as Miles- watching a seemingly invincible icon and personal hero get beaten by the bad guy. I felt Miles struggles with his dad and the expectations on him. When Miles finally gets in touch with his abilities and accepts that this is who he is, I truly felt for him. Hell, the Stan Lee cameo is even one of the most emotional scenes in the movie: my sister and I were both crying when we watched this in theaters the first time after his death. 
Ultimately, this movie is just a Spider-Man fans perfect movie, and this movie is an experience that I will always enjoy and remember fondly, and I regard it as one of if not the best animated/superhero movies of all time.

A must watch before you leave this planet film where it test the possibilities of what animation can advance to and maybe one day be in the rankings to aim for Best Picture with the right script and direction with the likes of the minds of three directors - Peter Ramsey, Rodney Rothman and Bob Persichetti, and the duo of Phil Lord and Chris Miller. Absolutely mind-blowing stylized animation that viewers will never have expected from the trailers. Sony really found its mark and style in the animation sector and hopes to bring the same quality in future installments and original IPs. A very diverse cast and who knew an African-American Hispanic Spider-man could be the new inspiration for the next generation of animators and story-tellers. Can't wait for the follow up sequel to this universe.

Normally whenever there is an introduction to a new alter-ego for a superhero we all know and love, it is often met with backlash. No one can accept Dick Grayson as Batman, Calvin Ellis as Superman,  Carol Danvers as Captain Marvel, Wally West as The Flash - the list goes on. And Spider-Man is one of, if not the most popular and likeable superheroes out there. So in such a condition replacing our beloved Peter Parker with some new random guy could have been a disastrous idea. But not only did this movie take the risk, we're glad it did.
Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse is the kind of a superhero animated movie I wanted to see - one with traditional animation done in the style of stereoscopic 3D, with continuous symbols of glitches. Personally I consider watching two superhero movies to be the most connected with watching a comic - Zack Snyder's Justice League and this. And out of the two ZSJL feels more like some painting more than an actual comic, so this one takes the cake for it. The speech bubbles, the panel swipes, the colour splashes; everything make this movie look like watching a Spider-Man comic come to life.
Personally I'm all in for the diversity in the characters. Normally I am annoyed when diversity is their only trait. When such a character is added just for the sake of existing, it just makes it look like a wasted effort, and what makes worse is that we can't even point it out without upsetting some people. Miles Morales, however, absolutely does not feel the same. The kind of a person he is, the way he turns into Spider-Man and meets the other heroes to learn more about who and what he is, everything seems to come out naturally.
The story is very well thought out, which is also another reason why it feels so natural. If I were given to introduce a character and bid farewell to the renowned one, I could have never done it as well as this did. It introduced many different types of Spideys, made us feel emotions for all of them, had us sympathise with the bad guys all the while making us laugh and cheer at the fights. See this is exactly what I'd want from a comic book movie, especially a superhero one. It should not just be, but actually feel like we are immersed into the environment, even though it is an animated movie.
My favourite character in this movie was Spider-Noir. He was hilarious as a detective, always talking about everything like it is supposed to be a mystery. He also looked cool, so there's also a plus to that. Then I also liked Miles Morales himself. Whatever the movie was wanting me to feel for him, I did so. As he builds his character development from being a clumsy teenager to the most powerful Spidey, it was a spectacle to watch.
I really wish to see more of these. Miles Morales is already one of my favourite characters now, so even if in future he slowly replaces Peter Parker as the face of Spider-Man, I won't feel bad about it. The recent PS5 game, if I hadn't watched the movie, wouldn't have received my interest no matter however good it was, since I would never accept anyone else as my Spider-Man. It really seems to be a great time to be a Spidey-fan. I hope it lasts long.

This movie is an absolute joy for comic book fans from start to finish. The animation is stellar, The story is amazing, and the humor is on point! Miles Morales is a very compelling version of Spider Man that is very relatable. This movie is an easy 10/10!

I would go as far as to say 'Spider-Man: Into the Spiderverse' is the most visually stunning film I've seen; with a truly unique and revolutionary comic-book-esque animation style, every frame is poster worthy. Its achievements are far from lying only in the aesthetic department, another standout feature for me being the the soundtrack. 'What's Up Danger' couldn't have been a more fitting superhero theme to match its urban hip-hop context, and other tracks such as Daniel Pemberton's 'The Prowler' will surely give you goose bumps.
Thankfully this film doesn't suffer from the ailment of previous Spidey films, either. We're introduced to an intricate web of wacky characters (looking at you, Peter Porker) without the plot being over muddled.
Congratulations to everyone involved in this clever modern classic that exploits the medium of animation to a new potential and shows us just how much more there is to discover in this realm of filmmaking.

First of all it doesn't even make sense, I went to my local Walmart and got in my mobility scooter, I placed my hand on some woman's shoulder and said "hey" just like the movie told me! Next thing I knew I was being wheeled out of the store for just listening to Spider-Man. 1 out of 5 stars because I had to get my pizza bagels from target next door.

Shameik Moore is good in the lead, while Jake Johnson supports competently in his role. Hailee Steinfeld, Nicolas Cage and Kathryn Hahn, as well as a few others, stick out too. Away from the already mentioned, I also like the music - having already known about "Sunflower".

Evidently it didn't connect to me, someone who has zero attachment to the source material, massively. That doesn't, though, change the fact that I did find enjoyment with 'Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse' and I would certainly recommend it.

I was torn between 3.5* and 4* for this but the higher won out due to just how spectacular it looks. However, this movie isn't as good as everyone makes it out to be. While it is a good movie, it is not nearly 'the best superhero movie ever' as I have seen some tout. There are some glaring plot issues (understandable with a multi-dimensional plotline) and a lot of the characters don't have anywhere near enough screentime or interaction with Myles to get the emotional sendoff the movie tries to shove down our throats. However, it is still a damn entertaining movie that got some genuine chuckles out of me at times. And Myles himself is a good character, as is fake Peter. It was just everyone else around them that felt a little flat, which again is understandable when introducing so many new characters into one movie. It was overall good, but not excellent like some suggest.

The story centers around a young man by the name of Miles Morales and he like any other teenager is struggling to find his place and where exactly he belongs in this life. Due to the curious nature of the boy, he stumbles upon an abandoned NYC subway tunnel which will prove to change Miles forever. Miles was bitten by a radioactive spider not unlike the same spider whose given Spider-Man his power. Naturally Miles turns to the only person he knows could help, the actual Spider-Man. Now caught in a fight against Wilson Fisk turns into this inter-dimensional clash, one the proved to be too much to handle for only two super-powered Spider-Men. Once messing with dimensions, Miles meets and recruits 5 other super-powered Spider-Men and women from their respective dimensions in this battle over time and space. Will Miles be able to take a leap of faith and finally let go for the sake of the universes?

I must say the animated visuals seen in this movie are pretty groundbreaking thought you either love it or hate it, i personally loved the comic book feel to the movie, a real strength of the picture. Decent... I'd recommend watching it... but it's definitely not the best they could have done. First, the things I absolutely love: the animation and music is some of the best I've ever seen. I love the comic book feel the movie creates. But, alas... the lesser great things in this movie: the characters are, for the most part, underdeveloped and most of the characters are shallow; some of the spider-person characters were just there to make a joke or two. Kingpin's backstory could have been fleshed out more to create a deeper antagonist, but we're just given one bit of backstory and that's that. And that's more I can say for the rest of the villains, or, Kingpin's villainous henchmen. But the biggest mistake in this movie is the main protagonist's father. Miles forges a kind of bond with his father by the end, through both himself (being the son) and on the other hand, Spiderman , and some character development took place, but I would have loved to see a lot more. Their relationship is still not where it should be, and the characters have a lot more development to undertake before I can picture their father-son relationship realistically.

If I had to describe this movie in one word, it would be unique. Everything about this movie just felt fresh and new to a genre that has been very saturated over the past few years. The entire film felt like it was told through this ADHD style lens that made each scene feel like you were right along side Miles. The action was fast paced and exciting, and it never failed to put a smile on my face. The movie also showed how well it is at balancing tones. One scene would make you cry, while the next made you laugh out loud, and the next would give you a sense of empowerment. The animation style was also pretty remarkable. It truly felt like a comic book brought to life. Every frame felt vibrant and lively, and you could really tell that the animators poured their heart and soul into. Overall, this movie was pretty damn amazing.

Spider-Man Into the Spiderverse provides a great coming of age story and a new spin on the story of the character of Spider-Man. It features the same aspects of the character such as family, friends, and responsibility in a new and bold way. The use of Miles Morales instead of Peter Parker as the main protagonist provides new angles and story telling devices. The use of the Kingpin as the main antagonist instead of other Spidey villains also helps to tie in the plot with the character, as the motives of Kingpin's plans look and seem justified while also reminding us about the true antagonist of the story. Overall, the plot, characters, and graphics all serve to create a dynamic movie never before seen in the big screen

I've watched this film around when it came out but decided to rewatch it again recently just because of the new Spider-Man: Miles Morales game. The premise of the movie is simply "Bitten by a radioactive spider in the subway, Brooklyn teenager Miles Morales suddenly develops mysterious powers that transform him into the one and only Spider-Man. When he meets Peter Parker, he soon realizes that many others share his special, high-flying talents. Miles must now use his newfound skills to battle the evil Kingpin, a hulking madman who can open portals to other universes and pull different versions of Spider-Man into our world". I absolutely adored it when it came out but do I still feel that way after rewatching it?

Firstly, the animation style and 3D models are absolutely amazing! While I do love the Pixar style of animation, this comic book style of animation was such a breath of fresh air in the animated film department. I also appreciate a lot of the aesthetic choices such as having this shaky movement instead of fluid which further makes it feel like a comic book come to life. The action scenes are also animated really well and are an absolute blast to watch as well. Clearly, a lot of thought went into this and it clearly shows in the movie. 

Miles Morales (Shameik Moore) is a great main lead. He isn't perfect and is actually very flawed with them making a fair amount of what would be frustrating mistakes. However, the directors succeed in still making us root for him as we can see how much he really wants to pull through for the team. Peter B. Parker (Jake Johnson) is another great Spiderman in this movie who is a mentor figure for Miles. He is a person who has been doing this spiderman business for over 20 years and has a lot of problems with his Peter Parker life such as his divorce with Mary Jane. Due to this, he is quite neglectful of Miles but he goes through his own character arc that is done very well. His chemistry with Miles is one of the things that really shine in this movie. Gwen Stacy/Spider-Woman (Hailee Steinfeld) is the third Spider character that appears in the movie and is mostly there to be the competent and supportive one in the group for Miles. The other three Spider characters Spider-Man Noir (Nicolas Cage),  Peni Parker (Kimiko Glenn) and Peter Porker (John Mulaney) are also all very distinct and different in personality which is perfectly converted despite small screentime. 

The cast is also phenomenal, everyone does a great job, especially Shameik Moore and Jake Johnson. There is also some other stellar casting like Brian Tyree Henry as Mile's dad, Mahershala Ali as Mile's Uncle Aaron, Chris Pine as Peter Parker of Mile's universe, Zoë Kravitz as Mary Jane, Kathryn Hahn as Doc Octopus, Liev Schreiber as Kingpin and even Oscar Issac for a mysterious role that I won't spoil. It's an all-star cast and even though some have small roles, Sony still went through with casting big known actors. They all do a great job. The excellent soundtrack further elevates this movie. Every time the Prowler is in the movie there is this horn in the soundtrack that makes him seem more threatening. Additionally, there are some pop, R&B, rap songs within the movie that all fit really well and gives more identity to the movie and characters. 

The story is simple yet intriguing enough to keep the audience engaged. It introduced the complex multiverse idea but doesn't overcomplicate it to make it distracting. There are multiple villains but the director makes sure the main focus of villains is Kingpin which is a good idea as multiple focus villains will make the plot feel convoluted. There is also excellent dialogue which is thanks to Phil Lord and Rodney Rothman. The jokes all land and the serious moments are heart-warming and the banter enjoyable. It's good dialogue and none feel wasted. 

If I have to give the movie a flaw then I would say it is kind of the Spiderman group dynamic. Spider-Man Noir, Peni Parker and Peter Porker don't interact much with Miles apart from being extremely harsh on him. It makes the last moments with these Spider characters not as strong. Miles also just become an extremely adept Spiderman because the plot needs him to be. It doesn't completely feel justified since it doesn't feel like he was provided with enough training to be that good. However, it doesn't break the movie and the sacrifices are understandable to keep this origin story in just under 2 hours.

Overall, Spider-Man into the Spider-verse is still one of the best-animated movies to come out in a long time. I still loved it after rewatching it. It's a fresh take on Spider-Man that we haven't seen before in a movie. If you haven't watched this movie yet then you must absolutely watch this movie. I can't wait for the sequel!

Before I explain what I think of this movie, i want to explain what I think of superhero movies as a whole;

Superhero movies typically get around 3-4 stars.  They're solid, they are entertaining, but they lack rewatchability and most of the visual effects look the same.  I even think some of the plots mesh together.  The only real reason people come to watch those films is for, let's face it, the action.  That's what a superhero film is about.  There are some exceptions, like the Dark Knight, but for the most part, superhero movies take themselves a little too seriously. 

The reason I bring that up is because SpiderVerse separates itself from the pack.  It does have action, but it also has some very likeable characters and some great dialogue.  There are even some emotional moments; depending on who you are, there are some scenes in the film that will make you cry.  Everything about this story works perfectly.

Of course, the biggest thing that separates this movie from animated films and superhero movies is the style.  Every frame of this movie is a comic book panel.  It's obvious that this was the intent, there are even onomatopoeia bubbles and dialogue boxes in some frames, but the aesthetic and framing of the movie also capture that.  This part stuck out to me because I LOVE comic books and graphic novels.

But, let's say you're not a fan of comic books or superhero movies [yes, those people exist].  If you are indifferent to that kind of thing, there is still an engaging, unique story, with engaging and unique characters.  The movie also has a great sense of humor, the type of humor that makes anybody laugh and smile.  

In short, the movie separates itself from the pack with clever writing, but what ultimately makes it a must-see is the stylistic presentation.  This movie is as beautiful on the outside as it is on the inside.

Spiderman Into the Spiderverse Review 
	Spiderman Into the Spiderverse is an animated film adaptation of the iconic superhero Spiderman. In into the Spiderverse a gifted teenager named Miles Morales becomes the one and, only Spiderman or so he thinks in his universe, and ends up teaming up with other Spiderpeople from other universes to stop a threat to all of their realities. Spider into the Spiderverse is a brilliant animated masterpiece, not only with mixing in traditional animation with computer animation, but with having many other typical elements that go along with animation such as humor and colorful characters. 
	Spiderman Into the Spiderverse pays tribute, not only to Spiderman, but to the animation genre in general. It pays tribute to traditional animation by showing traditional animation in the form of a comic book when one of the spidermen in the film whose name is Peter B Parker explains a plan he has to hack a computer. It also gives acknowledgment to classic animation simply by having a classical animated Spiderman in the form of a pig. It shows respect to anime by having an anime spiderwoman and to more modern animation by being mainly in the form of CGI. It gives nods to the original Tobey Maguire Spiderman films by showing some of the scenes from them over again in animation. It also plays the original main Spiderman theme song and features the old Spiderman cartoon that came out in the 60s. 
	The film has a fair amount of humor which is also admiring since animation traditionally and perhaps usually is associated with humor. If you notice during the opening scenes of the film when Mary Jane is kissing Spiderman it's Mary Jane hilariously hanging upside down instead of Spiderman. Peter B Parker sees a different version of himself which is not only a blond version of himself but a much nicer looking version of himself if you notice which is also amusing. There's also an inside joke when one of the spiderpeople asks if the spiderpig known as spiderham is legally allowed to say "that's all folks" after spiderham says, "that's all folks."
	Spiderman Into the Spiderverse creates plenty of diversity with its gaudy characters not only by having spiderpeople that are completely different from each other, but also by having a biracial person play Spiderman, and diversity adds tons of color. Spiderman into the Spiderverse is very different from the previous Spiderman films by being animated and this alone is very gaudy. I would love to see each spiderperson in the film of their own.   Particularly, Spidermannoir because seeing a film of his would be an authentically different Spiderman film. It would not only be animated but also in black and white, and I just may get my wish with there being talk and planning of a spinoff film. 
	Spiderman Into the Spiderverse is an animated masterpiece that is not only worth seeing, but also worth seeing more than once. I give Spiderman into the Spiderverse a 10 out of 10.

Truly original.I thought I had seen almost everything I could see in relation to Spider-Man, because he is one of those characters who insists on returning to the cinema with some regularity. To make matters worse, the industry, andTruly original.I thought I had seen almost everything I could see in relation to Spider-Man, because he is one of those characters who insists on returning to the cinema with some regularity. To make matters worse, the industry, and particularly Marvel, flooded theaters with films about cartoon characters, from the most famous to the most obscure, and this became repetitive, trivializing the genre.But this film has nothing to do with the others. In fact, instead of following the path of ultra-realism that other animated films have followed or limited to being a spin-off or reissue of the character's story, the film transports us totally to the world of comic books, assuming for you that stylized look that these publications have, and bringing a totally new and different story, with an African American Spider-Man who tries to succeed the original, after witnessing his death, and save the world from destruction with the help of several versions of the hero from various parallel universes. Even the famous Spider Pig (even those who have never seen the Simpsons know) will appear!The film features several famous actors who give the voice to the various characters (Shameik Moore, Jake Johnson, Mahershala Ali, Hailee Steinfeld, Nicolas Cage etc.) and is visually impressive, full of effects taken from the comic books on paper and a CGI state-of-the-art. The sound is also impressive, both in the action scenes and in relation to the soundtrack, where Hip Hop and suburban rhythms predominate. The pace of the film is quite fast, with breathtaking scenes.I had little expectations when I went to see this film, but I have to admit that it is truly exceptional. However, it turns out to be so bold and so different from the ordinary that this can make it indigestible to some audiences.

That being said, Spider-Man: Into The Spider-verse has proven to me to be among the most memorable films of the last decade. It has this incredible sense of charm, humor, and whimsy in way Spider-Man hasn't been able to capture since Spider-Man 2 in 2004. What's more, this is the most well-animated film I have ever seen, seamless blending a smorgasbord of styles while maintaining a magnificent sense of stylistic cohesion so as to not allow the numerous styles to crowd one another out.

The characters in this movie are also well fleshed out and contributed to the story significantly in one way or another.Miles Morales and Peter Parker and Spider-Gwen were the best characters and each were a delight to watch,funny and more. And shout out to (spiderman) the peter parker voice actor who usually acts in comedy did great voice work for Peter Parker and I can confirm is very different to what you see in love action films but really captures the feel of Spiderman.The movie was really bold as well from the different visuals the story involving parallel dimensions and universes which worked because you could see from glimpse that every universe felt different and unique.Also the film felt really mature even from a PG movie it felt like a hardcore PG film with its themes,drama and consequences especially the Kingpin charcter and a heartbreaking arc involving Peter Parker and I for one enjoyed that.The music was also nice.Miles Morales who the story is based on is a good lead from the voice acting and up. You could see the struggle he was dealing with trying be Spiderman and the responsibility of it and that's what Spidernan has always been about with great power comes.....you know the line.His character grows and develops over time as he dealt with the trails and tribulations of being Spiderman and by the end it payed off which was nice to see. The main Villain Kingpin had a compelling reason for his evil actions and has kind of intimidating a bit like like the Netflix Kingpin, which was a really mature take on a pg movie so agian another plus for the movie although there some generic bad guy things and dumb decisions that villians make in this movie but since its a kids movie i'll just let it slide.The other Spiderman people were really good too like Spiderman Noir, Spiderham and Pennie Parker were really entertaining with the screen time they were on though sometimes they felt have much variety sometimes compared too Spider Gwen,Peter Parket or Miles Morales.The action is pretty good as well and its done well with the comic book style animation as words or phrases would pop up on the screen like a comic book so that was fun and the comedy was really well timed and hasn't forced unlike the MCU movies it balanced the drama and humor aspect well in the movie.However my biggest gripe about the movie is that some character arcs weren't would fully resolved or plot holes per say especially for Miles Morales' Dad and his Uncle I cant go into details without spoiling but there was an issue that happened that semed it was forgotten about and never fully solved. Also just minor nitpicks is that you dont get to see Miles Morales be Spiderman for really long or really show off what he can do but I understand its an origin story so its understandable and sometimes the movie wanted to do some fourth wall breaking like Deadpool but only in minor moments which felt kind of out of place.So in the end there was very little wrong with this movie, I enjoyed almost every bit of it. It was funny, fun,colorful with really good animation,bold art style, amazing characters, blanced humor,great lessons about responsibility and courage and the drama was really well and was just an overall great movie. So again Well done Sony for making one of the best Spiderman movies ever and one of the best films of 2018.

I came into this movie with larger-than-life EXPECTATIONS. After a horde of online praise from both critics and users alike, not to mention instant Oscar buzz, I was primed for disappointment as i thought a movie can never be that good.II came into this movie with larger-than-life EXPECTATIONS. After a horde of online praise from both critics and users alike, not to mention instant Oscar buzz, I was primed for disappointment as i thought a movie can never be that good.I was huge Spider Man fan, from the first Sam Raimi movie to the 2nd, and then it stopped there. I watched the third movie in the franchise (and had to re-watch it just to make sure I didn't see it on a bad day) and was just thoroughly confused. The Andrew Garfield movies were just awkward to me and I just gave up.This new movie however? BALL-BUSTERS!From the opening image referencing the Comics Code Authority (I promise that would be the last and only spoiler this will have!) I knew right then and there that this movie means business, the business of not taking itself too seriously.I had my doubts about having "another" Spider Man or any other Spider Man for that fact. I never was a fan of the early nineties story arc of cloned versions of Peter Parker. I thought this would be another way of today's media just pissing on already existing beloved IP like the way CW is doing to Superman in their Super Girl series. I was ready for Sony to just poop all over Spider Man, especially now that he's part of the MCU. More on this point later.We're introduced to Miles Morales, a brilliant kid from Brooklyn who just wants to make his own mark in the world and find his own special place, just like everyone of us. He is a character that all us can relate to with his constant struggle with the mundane. Even worse, being a teenager while he's at it.It is a totally down-to-earth story filled with everyday stories about growing up and handling expectations, until that is, he gets bitten by a radioactive spider. If you feel like that's a spoiler, where the hell have you been hiding the past few decades? It's every Spider Man's right of passage, get bit by a Spider, be Spider Man.He then gets thrust into a the bizarre world of being Spider Man and along the way realizes that it's not all fun and games and yes, indeed, with great power comes great... No I won't finish that sentence, Peter!Being a comic-book movie, the action is non-stop but what really sets it apart from a sea of such movies is the absolute grandeur of all it.The wonderful set-pieces beautifully drawn and rendered, will make you believe that this alternate universe of Brooklyn really does exist, and makes you wish you live there instead. It's captures Brooklyn's hipster and art culture beautifully, just that short of being artistic. Mind you not Blade Runner 2049 artistic, It wont give you headaches and make you think about the meaning of life or anything. Just wonderful.The best part, apart from the visual orgasm, is the soundtrack. It is never obtrusive and always on point. Lead by the promotional singe "Sunflower" by Post Malone and Swae Lee, the hip-hop and pop inspired score and soundtrack is absolutely blissful. Ever since the Black Panther soundtrack blew me away, I feel that i now love this music in EVERYTHING.This may be a super-hero movie but this is an offering I highly suggest the whole family watch. It has everything for everyone, with nostalgic (and I do mean NOSTALGIC) easter-eggs and shout-outs for even the snootiest of fans to references to the culture for today's youth. I give that an absolute perfect score. This is what a super-hero movie should be like. Hands down MY favorite movie of the year.

E-Value: 9Acting: 9Plot: 9Similar to Venom which was released months ago, this is one of the perks from sharing the movie rights of Spider-Man between Sony and Disney. Unlike the previous Spider-Man movies, not only did Spider-Man receive an animated movie with a theatrical release for the first time but it also stars Miles Morales as Spider-Man instead of Peter Parker.Miles Morales (Moore) is a boarding school student, who admired Spider-Man as a hero. One day while hanging out with his uncle, Aaron Davis, in an abandoned subway, he was bitten by a radioactive spider which gives him similar abilities like Spider-Man. Later on, he discovers a secret laboratory where he witness notorious crime lord, Wilson Fisk/Kingpin (Schreiber), who is building a particle accelerator for some evil purpose and Spider-Man is trying to stop him.Although Spider-Man successfully disables the machine, Kingpin manages to kill him due to Spider-Man being wounded from the fight. With his death and identity exposed, the city mourns their beloved hero. Inspired by his death, Miles wants to fight crimes to honour him. He is then approach by what appears to be Peter Parker. Confused at first, Miles soon realise that this Peter Parker (Johnson) is actually from another universe where Miles does not exist and he is still Spider-Man but having trouble with his personal life.Both Peter and Miles learn that Kingpin’s particle accelerator have brought him to Miles’ universe. Peter reluctantly trains Miles to be Spider-Man while working together to stop Kingpin and brings Peter back to his universe using the same machine. They soon find out that Peter isn’t the only one in Miles’ universe as they are join by other Spider-Men from their respective universe including Gwen Stacy/Spider-Woman. Meanwhile, Kingpin is restoring his particle accelerator to use again for his upcoming plan.Although this movie is not made by Marvel Animation, the movie’s animation done by Sony Pictures Animation is very good and very artistic which actually resemble the actual comic book. The story of using multiverse concept for the movie is well written and utilised without making it complicated or confusion.The decision of using Miles Morales as Spider-Man is pretty much a good choice in my book because he is lesser known superhero to most people and Peter Parker’s Spider-Man have been very well known to everyone. This is a perfect opportunity for Miles Morales’ Spider-Man to shine.The voice acting is very good and the casts are managed to deliver their best performances. There are many funny moments which I laughed so many times and those moments make the movie very fun and entertaining to watch. This could be the best Spider-Man movie I have seen so far. Stan Lee had a voice cameo in this movie posthumously which I won’t spoil it here and you may not want to miss this movie. Having said this, I highly recommend you to watch this movie. Be sure to stay back for a post credits scene which could be a hint for future movies.

Before we start,I just need to point out that the best Spider-Man Movie (and best Comic-Book movie of 2018) is made by the same animated studio that delivered movies with fart and poop jokes as their trend. Onto the review.Let’s talk aboutBefore we start,I just need to point out that the best Spider-Man Movie (and best Comic-Book movie of 2018) is made by the same animated studio that delivered movies with fart and poop jokes as their trend. Onto the review.Let’s talk about the ‘Set-Up’ Movie. A ‘Set-Up’ Movie is a term that I often use to point out some cinematic garbage that milks money out of its production value just for the sake of setting up a big Cinematic Universe (that started all the way back in 2008 with Marvel Studios,precisely with Iron Man). Sony started this 4 Years Ago with The Amazing Spider-Man 2,a movie with some decency in its runtime,but still ruined by the likes of Alex Kurtzman’s “JJ Abrams Mystery Box” style writing,but it was later taken to a new level by Universal Pictures (Jurassic World Fallen Kingdom or The Mummy with their 3rd Acts).Now Sony is still trying to start their own Universe as of 2018 with movies like Venom (“When I get out of here...And I will...There’s gonna be Carnage”) and now Spider-Man Into The Spider-Verse,a movie that may be the best movie out of all these Set-Up Movies for the reasons it’s not supposed to work (but somehow,it does).Literally everything about this movie is flawless. Yeah,sure,there are some jokes that didn’t land as much as the previous one...Yeah,the Animation was interchangeable at times and yes,it has a soundtrack with classic hits (aside from Sunflower and What’s Up Danger?) that feels perfect for a dumb YA Movie,but who cares? There’s a real Entertainment value behind this movie,and it shows all its hard work put into this. It may also be the most Personal movie I’ve ever seen,considering the fact that Miles Morales (the main character of the movie,played by Shameik Moore) is me,but black and Spider-Man.Difficult relationship with his dad? Check.Being in the wrong school because of the dad’s reasons? Also Check.Always trying to save/help somebody out? Umm,hell yeah.This is my favourite Screenplay of the year for all these reasons and so much more,but also because it manages to combine all the previous Spider-Man outings (for example,the Raimi trilogy for its Origin story,the character getting beaten to the ground morally and….maybe too many villains?) and still trying to be a movie of its own,with new characters,frenetic action scenes (some of them brutal for a kids movie,where even Japanese media ain’t got nothing,even if that means whatever the hell that was in Akira),brilliant character development (we get to care about a living pork,for Pete’s sake) that is all accompained by fantastic animation. Sometimes it’s a living comic-book,sometimes it’s a Borderlands game,and sometimes a PS2 game (mainly for character animation),which keep in mind,makes sense for the world we’re watching.Th screenplay also manages to get excited for its future Cinematic Universe (with a sequel and an all-female spin-off already in development). When’s the last time you’ve seen a non-MCU Movie that got you excited for its universe of future movies? As I said before,the Screenplay also manages to get brutal at times,with a punch by a big buff dude like Kingpin that feels like the Apocalypse and a gunshot that kills a character. Again,when’s the last time you’ve seen a brutal non-Pixar animated movie?It also doesn’t stop to reference something classic for laughs and be Deadpool or LEGO Batman for a second,no no no,because the references are actually in favor of the story,whether it’s a character introduction or a post-credit sequence.Oh,and the 3D is so good,it’s honestly the best use of 3D since Avatar. Not even a second to be on screen and the colors pop out the screen on purpose,making this movie the best acid trip since 2001 A Space Odyssey. The Comic-Book effects leap as if we’re seeing a literal comic-book,and the image sometimes feels worthy of a Best Cinematography award.Overall,there’s really nothing to complain about in here. After walking out of the theater,I said to myself “Man,this one will be hard to write because everything about it is really good”,but no. I really had fun doing this. This is also the kind of guts a typical movie critic has. Usually,we enjoy talking TNTs about a bad movie,but sometimes,a good movie can feel like a new quest,a new journey in a movie critic’s life,and I didn’t think a Spider-Man movie would accomplish that (But again,this was a year where an Action Movie made me scream at an IMAX). I will come back at a new Sony Spider-Man movie full of hope,and luckily,with pure excitement. Please,go see this movie.It's really worth your time and pennies.

Was that very hard to make a very decent Spider-man movie, Sony?Spider-man: Into the Spider-verse is directed by Peter Ramsey, Robert Persichetti Jr. and Rodney Rothman, screenplay by Phil Lord and Rodney Rothman, and voices-starring byWas that very hard to make a very decent Spider-man movie, Sony?Spider-man: Into the Spider-verse is directed by Peter Ramsey, Robert Persichetti Jr. and Rodney Rothman, screenplay by Phil Lord and Rodney Rothman, and voices-starring by Shameik Moore, Jake Johnson, Hailee Steinfeld and Mahershala Ali.Story by Phil Lord, and it's about Brooklyn teen Miles Morales, and the limitless possibilities of the Spider-Verse, where more than one can wear the mask.First time I heard about this movie I wasn't that hype about the idea of the movie or the animation. The trailer wasn't so clear about its animation, or the very bold storyline! When I went to see this movie I was blown away by the striking animation and the bold storytelling.. I think it's a very risky step for Sony to take, to make a very unique, new and comic-alike animation, I mean what if the audience didn't like it? It could have been a big disappointing movie, because it has an amazing story, I think this story is definitely the best story of the whole Spiderman movies, also the animation is amazing, it's flawless! When an animation movie brings the live-action movies down, it means that it's definitely unique and bold!!The story didn't take so long to get you into the main plot, it went with its surprising "scene" -I'm not gonna spoil anything in this review- and though it made a very good introduction of the characters, so the first act was very good, shocking and humorous too!The second act still a very funny and thrilling as the first act, introducing the rest of the characters, so it took more time to get us back to the main plot, and I loved it, because some characters wasn't that clear in the first act that I wanted to know more about, and others that I wanted more of their backstories because I liked them! After introducing the "rest of the characters" we get another shocking scene, driving us to another shocking scene.. excuse me if I'm mysterious about some stuff, but I don't want to spoil anything, and still, if you watched the movie, you're gonna understand me very well.The third act was very predictable though, but still very thrilling because of its amazing animation combined with the amazing action, and emotions... Oh yeah, the third act is completely emotional, and action-full!There're not any subplots like Fantastic Beasts the Crimes of Grindelwald or something, it's very straight and clear.. very good for kids, and amazing for Spider-man fans and adults as well.I think that Spider-Man Into the Spider-verse is the Spider-Man that we deserve as fans of Spider-Man and it's definitely the best Spider-Man movie of all the time.! And of course, Spider-Man Into the Spider-verse gets an A+!Alright, guys.. thank you as always for reading and supporting my work, and if you liked this you can click on my name above and read all of my reviews, lots of movie-reviews are coming ahead.. thanks again!

This movie was a huge - and pleasant - surprise, 'Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse' isn't another live-action Spider-Man reboot from Sony, nor is it part of the Marvel Cinematic Universe. It's well and truly its own story that focuses on theThis movie was a huge - and pleasant - surprise, 'Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse' isn't another live-action Spider-Man reboot from Sony, nor is it part of the Marvel Cinematic Universe. It's well and truly its own story that focuses on the character of Miles Morales (Shameik Moore) and his pretty ordinary teenage life. Dealing with his father's moral ways because he's a cop, coping to get through school even though it's boring for him. Everything just gets routine for him, except for the one person he looks up to, his uncle Aaron Davis (Mahershala Ali) who gives him the right amount of confidence boost that he needs in his daily life. Miles also meets a young girl in his class, Gwen Stacey (Hailee Steinfeld), and she appreciates his wit and even odd - yet quirky - personality. One day, Miles stumbles across an incident that involves the evil Kingpin (Liev Schreiber) who has invented a device that can create portals from one universe crossing paths with another. A rift causes another Peter Parker (Jake Johnson) to slip through the vortex and enter the universe that Miles is in. Miles aspires to be just like Peter after he was also bitten by a radioactive spider, but Peter tells him that there is much to learn. It seems that Peter isn't the only one that crossed paths with Miles, as there are a handful of other "Spider-People" that somehow got lost into this universe too, from; Spider-Noir (Nicolas Cage), Spider-Gwen, Peni Parker (Kimiko Glenn) and Spider-Ham (John Mulany). They all team up to try and come up with a plan to get each of them home back to their own universes. The movie certainly is a breath of fresh air into a character we have seen in the movies so many times before. This may just seem like Sony - once again - trying to cash-in on the character, but thanks to a script by Phil Lord ('The LEGO Movie') and Rodney Rothman, it has heart and very self-aware humor that keeps it afloat. It acknowledges its silliness and embraces that, it's overstuffed but also is aware of that too. Most importantly, it captures the spirit of the Spider-Man character and the world (or 'worlds') that he inhabits. Sony has been desperately trying to adapt a Miles Morales story for years and years, and this is the best introduction for him, especially for people who may not be familiar with his story. The animation is eye-popping as well, making it feel like a comic book leaping off the pages. Overall, this movie is fun, fast-paced, touching and wildly funny. If you love Spider-Man, this might just be the movie you've been looking for since 'Spider-Man 2' (2004).

I Love love love love this movie. Don't get me wrong, it isn't particularly innovative in its story. Origin stories usually follow a certain track in order to include necessary features. The thing that makes this movie great is the way itI Love love love love this movie. Don't get me wrong, it isn't particularly innovative in its story. Origin stories usually follow a certain track in order to include necessary features. The thing that makes this movie great is the way it tells a story we all know. The characters: Great!! They are well fleshed out, and I rarely actually feel for a character in movies, but there was authenticity that just led to likable people, and the humor helped a lot.The plot: As said before, the story wasn't particularly special, but the pacing was fantastic. Each scene seamlessly bled into the next, and narrative momentum is something I think we, unfortunately, lack in modern movies, but this definitely had it. You won't feel like a scene is unneeded.The cinematography: DAMN was it good. You just have to see it to know what I mean, but the stylistic choices of the movie give it such an original feel and work as a story-telling tool that makes it fresh and new. It's just a beautiful movie if you only care about that.Overall: It was an emotionally resonant, visually stunning, and narratively exciting movie that is near-perfect, and by far, one of my favorite super-hero movies ever :)

(NO SPOILERS)It has been a long time since I have seen a film that resonated with me on so many levels. There is clearly so much passion and care put into this project, and it is hard to believe that the same company released the 'Emoji(NO SPOILERS)It has been a long time since I have seen a film that resonated with me on so many levels. There is clearly so much passion and care put into this project, and it is hard to believe that the same company released the 'Emoji Movie' this year. I could harp on for hours about all the positives of this movie, but for your ease of reading, here are the highlights broken down into a digestible list:1) Art style. Seriously, it's phenomenal the level of detail in this film, and we may never see an artistic vision executed so thoroughly and expertly in this kind of movie again. Nearly every frame could be hung on a wall for a Comic Book Gallery.2) The dialogue and acting are on point, with smart, snappy exchanges between both believable and lovable characters. All the vocal performances are fitting for the characters and bring the story to lift.3) The soundtrack, good song choices that are well integrated into the film, complimenting the scenes they cover without distracting from the story.There are lots of other positives, but I think the best way to understand them would be for you to go an see this for yourself. Films this good need your support!

Best Comic Book Movie of All Time! This is not a summer blockbuster action movie. This is a comic book movie. It makes use of unique comic book innovations in its graphic design and layouts. It almost like they let Marvels world class comicBest Comic Book Movie of All Time! This is not a summer blockbuster action movie. This is a comic book movie. It makes use of unique comic book innovations in its graphic design and layouts. It almost like they let Marvels world class comic artists go to work and make their movie. The quality of the action sequences is unmatched. The use of layers of text and animation is brilliant. If you are a true comic book fan, you must see this film while its still in theaters. You probably cant see this in IMAX, but check it in Real 3D and sit in the front five rows to get an immersive VR like experience. The use of animation layers is ground breaking.  If you think the animation was scribble... Then you don't know the work of one of top two greatest comic book artists of all time, Bill Sienkiewicz. Expressive energetic use of lines and and textures give this film an extra edge beyond any animated movie you have seen. The story walks the line between formulaic Hollywood sentimentality and over the top comic book bombast and delivers something both familiar and groundbreaking. The character animation and voice performances are charismatic and believable. The new Spiderman feels real. He feels modern and relevant. There is no comic book franchise reboot that is this daring and successful. It makes Thor: Ragnaraok seem tame and conservative. This is the new bar that all super hero movies will be judged. It makes every super hero movie before it seem dated and obsolete and It raises the bar for all animated movies. Bravo!

A visually beautiful, superbly crafted, well acted, Spider-Man movie that encapsulates all the crazy multi-universe stuff that's been going on in Peter Parker's world (or I should say, worlds) in the Marvel comic books for the past couple ofA visually beautiful, superbly crafted, well acted, Spider-Man movie that encapsulates all the crazy multi-universe stuff that's been going on in Peter Parker's world (or I should say, worlds) in the Marvel comic books for the past couple of decades. I would give it a 10 for its heart, it's capturing of the various character personalities, and the skill with which it introduces us to the complex tapestry of multiple universe stuff while still finding plenty of time to tell a good story.However, I take off two points (I was tempted to take off 5) for one gigantic, and I mean gigantic, gaffe.If you've kept up with the Spider-Man comics, you know there are multiple parallel universes within the Marvel scheme of things, each one with tweaks and modifications: in one, Peter Parker died and Miles Morales was then bitten by a super duper spider and became Spider-Man; in another, Gwen Stacy was bitten by the spider and became the super hero; her Peter Parker died, too. In our universe, of course, the biggest event in comic book history took place some years back. Gwen Stacy, to whom Peter Parker was engaged, was murdered before his very eyes by the Green Goblin. Spider-Man comics have reiterated and revisited and reminded us of this tragedy consistently ever since. Everyone knows about it. In fact, part of the reason the comic book telling the adventures of parallel universe Gwen has been so successful, is because it is so wonderful to see a version of Gwen who is still alive and, who to boot, is a super hero in her own right.So it is nothing short of bizarre when in the movie, Peter Parker, our universe Peter Parker, doesn't even recognize his fiancee's twin from another dimension. She recognizes him, but he's oblivious. This just doesn't make sense. It's like a parallel universe version of Lois Lane showing up and Superman not recognizing her. It's a gaffe the size of the Grand Canyon. And a huge disappoint in what was otherwise an nearly perfect comic book movie.

I have a new favorite Spider-Man film!Into the Spider-Verse looks amazing. I've seen combinations of two- and three-dimensional animation before, but not anything like this. The movie is very colorful and makes excellent use of action. TheI have a new favorite Spider-Man film!Into the Spider-Verse looks amazing. I've seen combinations of two- and three-dimensional animation before, but not anything like this. The movie is very colorful and makes excellent use of action. The whole thing is supposed to look like a comic book and has some wildly creative ideas, including color slightly popping off the lines and thought captions and bubbles. This movie takes place in an alternate reality from more traditional Spider-Man timelines, giving the creators liberty to come up with some inventive visual twists on classic Spider-Man villains without feeling like real betrayals to the characters.Now, the movie does have a couple things that I adjusted to but may bug people with more sensitive eyes. As mentioned, the color is off-line and the background in particular can be blurry-looking. The motion frame rate is a little jerky, which I assume is a stylistic choice.The plot is equally impressive. The film features Spider-Men from multiple dimensions and multiple other characters yet manages balance and develop them all almost seamlessly. (Wouldn't have minded a little more time on Mile's relationship with his uncle, but that's a minor issue.) The comedy and drama is equally good. The movie has fun, but there are also stakes. There is real loss in this. (Parents who are more selective in what their children watch, may consider this more of a "big boy" film).The movie stars Spider-Man Miles Morales (voiced by Shameik Moore), who started off in Marvel's Ultimate comic line. He became popular enough that when the Ultimate universe was shut down, because Ultimate Spider-Man was the only real big seller, he was transferred to the main Marvel line. Hardcore Peter Parker fans may be upset that he isn't the star, but they did such a great job with Miles' character that I don't think you'll mind. He is likable and has personal issues like Peter, but in his own unique way. He forms a mentor relationship with a down-on-his-luck and world-weary Peter Parker (New GIrl's Jake Johnson), and the two of them have great chemistry and basically make the movie.This is one of those truly innovative steps in moviemaking and a sincere homage to comic books.
I don't know what to say. This is the best film of 2018, no questions asked.

I didn't quite expect this level of good when going to the cinema - Into The Spider-Verse ended up delivering on pretty much everything.The jokes are actually funny - no underage cringy garbage shoehorned by Disney into their movies.I didn't quite expect this level of good when going to the cinema - Into The Spider-Verse ended up delivering on pretty much everything.The jokes are actually funny - no underage cringy garbage shoehorned by Disney into their movies. Possibly the biggest swing with the best result of the entire year, it's not simply the fact that "Spider-Man: Into The Spider-Verse" is so many things, but it's the fact that it's so many things executed outstandingly well that makes itPossibly the biggest swing with the best result of the entire year, it's not simply the fact that "Spider-Man: Into The Spider-Verse" is so many things, but it's the fact that it's so many things executed outstandingly well that makes it possibly the year's best comic-book movie, nay *movie* (arguably). I'm a simple guy. I walk into an animated movie, I ask for two things. Number one -- tell me an interesting story. And number two -- make it look good. And, dear God, does this do both of those things to an almost excruciatingly original degree. Add my favorite Marvel character and one of my favorite working creatives -- Phil Lord -- into that mix and you get something I never even realized could turn out as objectively magnificent as this. This is a fantastically deep study on not only what the idea of "Spider-Man" means to the characters within the film, but what it means to all people -- including the audience. Spider-Man, the movie posits, is not just a hero, an example, or a cultural fixture, but a mechanism to help people believe in things bigger than themselves. Yes, the movie is that deep. And, boy, does it work. One of the only movies I've seen this year that immediately made me want to about-face my happy ass back to the box office and buy another ticket. It's pure, cinematic candy at its finest.

The movie is incredible. It’s not just the Ultimate Spider-Man, it’s the ULTIMATE Spider-Man movie. Most movies tend to focus on a few characters and forget the rest or focus on lots of characters, but they don’t have enough screen time forThe movie is incredible. It’s not just the Ultimate Spider-Man, it’s the ULTIMATE Spider-Man movie. Most movies tend to focus on a few characters and forget the rest or focus on lots of characters, but they don’t have enough screen time for each of them. The movie pulls it off where each character is on screen for an appropriate amount of time where you can invest your emotions in each one of them. You can also distinguish each character due to their unique personalities and designs. And every single character is redeemable (except for the main villain). The art style is bold and expressive and it makes the movie stand out above many motion animated pictures. It fits so well with the peoples’ and the environment’s actions as you are going through the movie, and it does not ever seize to amaze me. The story is great with relatable characters and as well as an adventure filled with comedy, heart, and passion. It’s pacing only feels slow once or twice and it always manages to catch my attention no matter which scene I am watching. The combination of the art and the story makes the movie feel interesting and I get invested with it all. In the end, it’s a movie full of not only comedy and self-referential parts, but it’s also a movie with (again) heart, passion, and effort. Which is what all movies should be made with today. A+

rt_summary: Bitten by a radioactive spider in the subway, Brooklyn teenager Miles Morales suddenly develops mysterious powers that transform him into the one and only Spider-Man. When he meets Peter Parker, he soon realizes that there are many others who share his special, high-flying talents. Miles must now use his newfound skills to battle the evil Kingpin, a hulking madman who can open portals to other universes and pull different versions of Spider-Man into our world.
meta_summary: Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse introduces Brooklyn teen Miles Morales, and the limitless possibilities of the Spider-Verse, where more than one can wear the mask.
